captions.text:
You might not be able to tell from the
outside, but the 5th generation

M3 represents a big change for BMW. It's
the engine.
Where high rolling naturally aspirated engines have characterized
the M3 since the 80's the straight 6 powering this 2015 M3
has not 1 but 2 turbos hanging off its side.
Claimed horsepower increased by 11 to 425,
but torque makes a huge jump
to 406 pound-feet
An increase of over a hundred pound feet and arrives much sooner. What's more
promising is that despite being

bigger in every dimension than the car it
replaces BMW says this M3 is lighter
than last generation
and significantly stiffer which will improve handling
and steering feel.
Driving the M3 was a very exciting prospect.
So you can imagine we were disappointed when we arrived at a wet and very
rainy Road America.

It's a fantastic course just over four
miles spread over fourteen turns in
two straights where the M3 can get close to it's electronically limited
155 mile an hour top speed.
For introduction of the new M3 we went to Road America for the press
launch
and it's been wet all morning.

It's been interesting you might think
that bad, but you know

you make lemonade out of lemons. It's
actually been a really good way
to learn the car to learn the differences between this and the E90
the previous generation M3 and the one that jumps out
is power.
This makes over 100 pound feet or torque more
than the last M3's V-8.

And you feel that instantly the torque
comes on so quickly

and so strongly that you really have to
anticipate that
especially if you're in the wet.
The last M3 made what 295 pound feet at 4000 RPM this
is a completely different animal than that.
And if you drive this car expecting that kind of power delivery
you're going to get pretty sideways.

You have to relearn how to drive this
car much like you had to relearn
driving the M5
when it got turbo charged
in a way that's a good segue because
my initial impression from driving this car in the wet is
that it feels
like a small M5.
And I think there are a couple reasons for that most specifically its
partly because this car uses this M5's differential
it uses the M5's transmission even the gear ratios are the same.
And the rear subframe gives you the same sensation that car does.
I think there's a Pro shoe behind us definitely (laugh)
we just got dive bombed by a BMW
professional driver anyway so M3.
Two reasons why this car gives me a similar feeling as an M5 is because
it uses the same twin clutch transmission
and it uses the same differential.
There's also similar philosophies in the rear end the rear end is very stiff

the sub frame is bolted directly to the
chassis like it is in the M5
and the result is they feel kind of similar.

And also despite this engine having two
turbochargers hanging off it there's a lot
of noise in the cabin.
It makes a remarkable amount of interior noise.
Engine noise.
The downside is it doesn't
sound as good as the E90's V8.
That's something you'll run into when comparing an 8000, 9000 RPM
V8
with a twin turbo
6-cylinder.

That said this thing does rev out nicely
and it has a very broad
power block.
BMW stresses the fact they've stiffened the chassis
quite a bit
I never doubt what the car's doing it feels consistent it feels controllable.
Feels communicative.
Like all the things you hope an M3 would feel like.

The newfound power has made a big
welcome impact on the way the M3
drives

but we wanted to see the size of that
effect. Once the M3 was back in Los Angeles

we took it to K&N Engineering and put
it on the dyno.
The result: 379 horsepower at
6600 rpm and 378 pound feet of torque

at 4300 rpm but peak numbers are less
important in the shape of the curve.
Look how quickly torque spikes when you press the throttle
and look how consistent the power delivery remains. For comparison
we also brought along an E92 M3.
Now look at the area under the curve
the difference is that big.

BMW launch control hasn't been the
greatest as of yet especially with the M5.
In this car it's better,

but still not great to activate it you turn off
stability control, traction control,
you select Manual mode on the shiffer, you make sure it's in the harshest

shift setting and if you want to do a big
burn out you hold the brake,

press the gas, and that's how the BMW
recommends
you use launch control. In our testing we actually found it slightly faster
to not hold the brake and just stab the throttle like that.
Minimal wheel spin at a fast 0 to 60 time
is what BMW recommends 3.9 seconds to 60.
Quarter mile low 12s.

Nearly a hundred and twenty miles an
hour not quite there but very fast.

We have the optional big carbon ceramic
rotors,
19-inch wheels and combined they should produce very short stopping distances.
Our best stop from 60 took just 99 feet.
Finally limit handling in the M3 in the dry.

What I really like about this chassis is that
it's flexible.
Ok M3 is good M3 gets the stamp of approval.
Most cars when you get into a big understeer/oversteer situation
that's the only thing the car's going to do and you're not going to be able to
control it get yourself out of it and fix it.
And this through the steering
through your throttle and brake inputs
you can very much control the line of the car.
And do some pretty big smoky drifts.
Or drive thru a course fast.
Lot of accuracy and feedback from the steering.
Lot of feedback in the chassis too.
This is the M3 we've been asking for.
The road and tire noise are loud the ride is firm.

But this is all done as it makes the car
drive better.

the steering is fantastic the field the
chassis in response as it gives back to you
make you want to
drive the car harder.

while the engine doesn't have the
theatrics of previous m3's

its power delivery more than makes up
for it.

title: 2015 BMW M3: Restoring the Faith, BMW M is Back! - Ignition Ep. 112
